docs.lead_paragraph: NORWOOD residents like to boast that their neighborhood is like the United Nations. All continents on the globe are represented in the population of the north central Bronx community. Even more to the point, longtime residents say, like the U.N.'s General Assembly, Norwood has a long tradition of vibrant, sometimes raucous, community meetings over issues ranging from the health of the trees on Mosholu Parkway to local hospital services and Bangladeshi cultural programs at neighborhood schools. A working-class community, Norwood is an island of densely packed winding streets set amid some of the city's finest parkland. The 1,132-acre Van Cortlandt Park sprawls along its western border, Woodlawn Cemetery stretches to the north and the New York Botanical Garden marks the neighborhood's eastern edge. Its southern boundary is the tree-lined Mosholu Parkway.

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In /Norwood; A Miniature U.N. Bordered by Parkland

docs.abstract: Profile of Norwood section of Bronx as place to live; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The shares of Autocyte Inc. jumped yesterday after Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said it would pay claims for use of Autocyte's Pap smear technology. Autocyte shares rose 42 percent, gaining $2.625, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading. Aetna announced on Thursday that it would reimburse customers for Pap smear systems made by Autocyte, the Cytyc Corporation and Neopath Inc. The smears are used to detect cervical cancer. Autocyte's system is used to prepare samples of cervical cells for analysis. Aetna's coverage of the technology, one of the first for Autocyte by a major United States insurer, bolsters claims that its system, though costlier than older technology, is more cost-effective in the long run and more accurate, analysts said.

headline.main: AUTOCYTE SHARES RISE AFTER AETNA ANNOUNCEMENT

docs.abstract: Shares of Autocyte Inc jump after Aetna Inc, biggest US health insurer, says it will pay claims for use of Autocyte's Pap smear technology; Aetna says it will reimburse customers for Pap smear systems made by Autocyte, Cytyc Corp and Neopath Inc; smears are used to detect cervical cancer (S)9

docs.lead_paragraph: The physical boundaries of Dave Hickey's world are clear enough. He lives in a nondescript apartment complex improbably called Country Club Towers, wedged in a triangle made by the Las Vegas Country Club, the Las Vegas Convention Center and the World Trade Center Hotel and Casino, a low-rent gambling hall with a line of faux Grecian statues in the front. He has a sunshine-to-neon, skyline-to-mountain view of that singular slice of the American landscape, the Las Vegas Strip. But the parameters of Mr. Hickey's intellectual universe seem limitless. His gentle, nicotine-laced drawl drifts effortlessly from Rembrandt to Norman Rockwell, from Jackson Pollock to ''Perry Mason,'' from Willie Nelson to Andy Warhol and back around to Robert Mitchum. He's a writer who learned to make prose by listening to the ''long, lapidary lines'' of Chet Baker's jazz trumpet, and he's a former Nashville songwriter and musician who once copied out the first 50 pages of ''The Great Gatsby'' ''just to see what it looked like to have good writing come out of your typewriter.''

headline.main: Unsettling the Art World for a Living; A Critic Resurrects Beauty as a Standard, and Finds It in Unexpected Places

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company's largest union voted overwhelmingly Wednesday night to accept a three-year contract, averting a strike that would have dealt a blow to Boeing's efforts to recover from a financial downturn. Of the votes cast by members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 44,300 of Boeing's 207,000 employees, 86 percent, or 26,842, were for the contract. A simple majority was required for passage.

headline.main: Challenges for Boeing After Union Approves Pact

docs.abstract: Boeing Co's largest union, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, votes overwhelmingly to accept three-year contract, averting strike that would have dealt blow to Boeing's efforts to recover from financial downturn; while both union and company hail the vote, Boeing still faces large challenges, such as market conditions and cost of new contract; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From the moment he began thinking about running for the United States Senate from New Jersey, Jon S. Corzine, the former chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has been attacked by his rivals as too rich to identify with workers, too suburban to care about the urban poor, too Wall Street to understand small-business owners on Main Street. But in recent weeks, as his campaign for the Democratic nomination has started taking shape, Mr. Corzine has been vigorously promoting himself as a rich but humble guy who can appeal to the party's core constituencies: women, blacks and union workers.

headline.main: A Vast Fortune, Liberal Views, a Political Dream

docs.abstract: Jon S Corzine, Democratic candidate for US Senate from New Jersey, is former chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Co who has been promoting himself as rich but humble guy who can appeal to women, blacks and union workers; Corzine's positions place him solidly in liberal wing of his party, roughly same ideological ground held by his main Democratic competitor, former Gov Jim Florio, and man he wants to replace, Sen Frank R Lautenberg; Corzine photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company's largest union voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a proposed new three-year contract, averting a strike that would have dealt a blow to Boeing's efforts to recover from an embarrassing financial downturn. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 44,300 Boeing employees, mostly in the flagship passenger jet division, said that the contract won the endorsement of 86 percent of those who voted. A simple majority was required for passage.

headline.main: Biggest Union at Boeing Votes To Accept Proposed Contract

docs.abstract: Boeing Co's largest union, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, votes overwhelmingly to accept proposed new three-year contract; new contract makes Boeing workers among best paid in country, raising hourly wages nearly 16 percent over three years to average of $24.35 an hour; other provisions noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The board of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company approved plans today to convert the company, the sixth-largest United States policy-holder-owned life insurer, to a publicly traded company. An initial stock sale is expected by the end of March. John Hancock, based in Boston, is one of a handful of large United States mutual insurers making the switch to public ownership, a move that gives them stock to make acquisitions, reward employees and raise money. Analysts said the company could be worth close to $10 billion on the stock market.
docs.abstract: Board of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co approves plans to convert company to publicly traded company; initial stock sale is expected by end of March 2000 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the nation's labor unions struggle to reverse their decline, they are focusing increasingly on an immense group that they have long overlooked: young workers. Yesterday, the labor movement took a new tack in seeking to court that group, releasing a survey that it had commissioned on young workers' attitudes toward their jobs, the economy and unions.

headline.main: Asking Its Views, Labor Woos the Young

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO, seeking to woo younger workers, releases survey on young workers' attitudes toward their jobs, economy and unions; study, run by Peter D Hart Research Associates, found young workers are concerned about many of same issues unions have been stressing; AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney, noting fewer than half of young workers surveyed have employer-sponsored health insurance or employer-funded pensions, holds today's jobs fail to meet basic needs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Anti-Independence Militias Resurface in East Timor Anti-independence thugs who have terrorized East Timor for months reasserted themselves in Dili, the tiny capital city. Though the referendum on the region's future on Monday was extraordinarily peaceful and officials said 98.6 percent of eligible voters had cast ballots, the thugs, who were mobilized into irregular militias by the Indonesian military, set up roadblocks in the capital and on rural roads. A10 Airliner Crashes in Argentina An Argentine Boeing 737-200 carrying at least 100 people crashed on takeoff in Buenos Aires. Early reports estimated up to 80 people killed and 23 people injured, including motorists and pedestrians. A5 Another Quake Hits Turkey The strongest tremor to hit northwestern Turkey since the earthquake on Aug. 17, which killed more than 14,000 people, shook the already devastated towns in the area. At least one person was killed. A3 Explosion in Moscow An explosion rocked the Manezh shopping center, wounding 30 people and bringing the threat of terrorism close to the Kremlin. The explosion coincided with a surge in fighting in Dagestan, in the Caucasus. A11 U.S. Aid to Russia Questioned Investigations into money laundering and capital flight out of Russia are pressing the Clinton Administration to justify policies of bold economic assistance to Moscow. A6 New Oil Chief in Venezuela President Hugo Chavez, left, solidified his control over Venezuela's state-run oil monopoly by appointing an ally as chief of the company, which controls the largest reserves of oil outside the Middle East. A3 Rebels Sign Congo Pact The divided rebels in Congo signed a peace agreement, a key step toward ending fighting in the country. The agreement calls for a cease-fire within 24 hours. Other combatants -- Rwanda, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Angola, Namibia and Congo itself -- signed last month. A3 World Briefing A4 NATIONAL A14-20 F.B.I. Chief Backing Independent Waco Inquiry The F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, favors an outside investigation of the bureau's failure to disclose the use of incendiary devices on the last day of the deadly confrontation with the Branch Davidian sect near Waco, Tex., in 1993, a spokesman said. Attorney General Janet Reno was said to be near the same conclusion. A1 Business's Rebuff to Senator Leaders of a committee of business executives who have endorsed a ban on unlimited campaign contributions said their members would not be intimidated by an aggressive letter-writing campaign led by Senator Mitch McConnell, above, Republican of Kentucky, one of the Senate's most ardent opponents of a bill to overhaul the campaign finance system. A1 AIDS Rate High in U.S. Prisons The prevalence of AIDS among prisoners is five times that of the general population, and the rates for some other sexually transmitted diseases are even higher, scientists said. A14 On Young Workers' Minds The biggest concerns among workers age 18 to 34 are falling behind the cost of living, lacking time for family responsibilities and being unable to afford to educate their children, a study for the labor movement found. Only 45 percent had employer-sponsored health insurance, and 43 percent had pension plans to which their employers contributed. A16 New Standards for Car Seats The first phase of a three-year Federal plan to create a universal, easy-to-use system for car safety seats for children takes effect today with stricter standards for head protection. The goal is to eliminate confusion among parents that results in incorrect installation of up to 80 percent of car seats. The Government estimates that the new system will save up to 50 lives and prevent 3,000 injuries per year. A15 Empathy for Striking Teachers Many parents in Detroit, a heavily unionized city, lined up to support a teacher strike that left many parents unexpectedly spending what was supposed to have been the first day of school with their children. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 U.S. Judge Overrules City And Orders Rally Permit A Federal judge ordered New York to grant a permit to organizers of a youth rally in Harlem planned for Saturday, saying officials could not use the content of Khallid Abdul Muhammad's inflammatory speeches as a basis for denying the permit. The city appealed and arguments were set for this morning. A1 Mayor Defends Police Shooting Mayor Giuliani defended the fatal police shooting of a mentally disturbed, hammer-wielding man in Brooklyn. The killing of Gidone Busch, 29, left, drew harsh criticism from some residents and local officials. A1 Juror No. 1's Day Mayor Giuliani listened to testimony as a member of a Manhattan jury in the case of a Harlem couple who are suing their landlord. B1 New York City on 01/01/00 The consensus among witnesses at a City Council hearing was that New York has little to worry about from the Year 2000 computer problem. B1 Clinton House Deal Near The Clintons appeared to be in the final stages of negotiations for a rambling Dutch Colonial in the Westchester village of Chappaqua. B5 EDUCATION B9 College Board Scores College Board exam scores remained roughly constant, compared with the previous year. B9 ARTS E1-10 Tenor Settles With Germany Luciano Pavarotti paid an undisclosed sum to a German court to settle a tax evasion case. E1 SPORTS D1-10 Ailing Stars Quit U.S. Open Pete Sampras and Patrick Rafter withdrew, citing injuries. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-18 Dollar Slips in Asia and Europe The dollar fell below 110 Japanese yen, reflecting a slide against the yen and the euro as investors renew interest in rebounding economies. C1 End of the Beanie Babies? The maker of Beanie Babies created a frenzy by announcing that ''all Beanies will be retired'' as of Dec. 31. Executives declined to elaborate. C1 Rebuff to Chase Overture Top executives at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter were said to have discussed -- and rejected -- a merger offer from Chase Manhattan. C1 Analyzing On-Line Revenue A new way to analyze Internet retailers' financial reports indicates that some of the highfliers may be coming back to earth. C1 Business Digest C1 OBITUARIES B11 DINING F1-14 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Mr. Holbrooke's return to Kosovo; the march and the Constitution; complacency amid the AIDS epidemic; Eleanor Randolph on Hillary's campaign companion.
